bibl.title: Bibliography: Articles on Yellow Fever and Malaria, by Henry Rose Carter, [19--]

div1.p: This bibliography lists the articles on yellow fever and malaria written by Carter.

div1.head: Bibliography: Articles on Yellow Fever and Malaria, by Henry Rose Carter, [19--]
div1.p:
Carter
Bibliography
(Copy of W. H. F)

list.head: ARTICLES ON YELLOW FEVER AND MALARIA, BY DR. H. R. CARTER, U.S. PUBLIC HEALTH SERVICE.
list.item:
1. A note on the interval between infecting and secondary
cases of yellow fever from the records of the yellow
fever at Orwood and Taylor, Miss., in 1898; New Orleans
Medical 3 urs. Journal, Vol Lii, pp. 617-619 May, 1900. Also, Ann. Rept. Marine Host.
Service, 1900.

2. “The period of incubation of yellow fever in man: a study from unpublished observations” (Planned
with (1) and (3) and written about the same time -
the trilogy forming a complete work). Published in
Medical Record, Feb. orin Aug. Mar. 1901 Vol LIX 362-367. Original manuscripts
deposited as a permanent loan.

3. A note on the spread of yellow fever in houses. Ex-
trinsic incubation. Medical Record, June 15, 1901 Vol LIX, pp 933-937.
Also in Ann. Rept. M. H.S., 1900. (Appeared in print
probably some time in 1901; certainly after Nov. 1900).

4. Mortality of yellow fever in Havana from 1886 to
1900. Public Health Reports, July, 1900.

5. A correlation of some facts in the propagation of
yellow fever with the theory of its conveyance by the
culex fasciatus. (Written in Nov. 1900, while sick at
the Johns Hopkins Hospital). The Phila. Med. Jour.
April 6, 1901.

6. Are vessels infected with yellow fever? Some personal
observations. Medical Record, March 22, 1902; Also in
Yellow Fever Institute Bulletin No. 9, 1902, 11 pp.

7. The methods of the conveyance of yellow fever infec-
tion. Yellow fever Institute, Bull. No. 10, July 1902.

8. Some characteristics of stegomyia fasciata which ef-
fect its conveyance of yellow fever, Med. Record,
May 14, 1904.

9. The conveyance of yellow fever. Medical News, November
5, 1904.

10. A memorandum from Panama experience showing that yellow
fever was contracted during the daytime. Written April
6, 1906. Published Medical Record, 1906.

11. Notes on the sanitation of yellow fever and malaria
from isthmian experience. (Written for Pan-American
Scientific Congress, held at Santiago, de Chilè, Dec.
1908, to January, 1909). Medical Record, July 10, 1909.

12. Yellow fever, its epidemiology, prevention and con-
trol. (lectures delivered March 26 and 27, 1914).
Supplement No. 19 to the Public Health Reports,
Sept. 11, 1914.

13. The period of incubation of yellow fever; A study
from unpublished observations. Read before the
Third Pan American Medical Congress, held at Habana,
Feb. 4, 5,6, and 7, 1901. Original manuscript de-
posited as a permanent loan. (?)

14. Immunity to yellow fever. Ann. Tropical Med. and
Parasitology, Vol. X, Apr. 1916.

15. Spontaneous disappearance of yellow fever from failure
of the human host; Trans. Soc. Tropical Med. & Hyg.
June, 1917.

17. Yellow fever in Peru; Epidemic of 1919 and 1920;
Ann. Jour. Tropical Hygiene, Vol. II, March 1922.

18. Preferential and compulsory breeding places of Aedes
(stegomyia) aegypti and their limits; Ann. Trop. Med.
and Parasitology Vol. XVIII, Dec. 1924.

19. The chance of the extension of yellow fever to Asia
and Australia; 1925?
Australasia. Proceedings of The Pan-Pacific Science
Congress, Australia, 1923. V. II, p. 1377-1388;

16. The mechanism of the spontaneous elimination
of yellow fever from endemic centres. Ann. trop.
med. and parasitology, vol. 13 March, 1920.

div1.p:
Dr. Carter is also the author of the
Sections on Yellow Fever in
(a) Nelson's Loose-Leaf Medicine:
(b) Practice of Medicine in the Tropics.
Byam: Oxford Press, London, 192
(c) A System of Pediatrics.
Abt (Isaac), Saunders, N. Y. 192
(d) History of Yellow Fever (not yet published)
